raw_text:
Prime minister's questions
 
 So who, if anyone, is playing politics with the security of the nation?
 
 Michael Howard has no doubt it is the prime minister who, he claims, is "ramming" through Parliament the controversial new anti-terror measures without proper debate. He didn't say so, but the Tories believe the prime minister is playing the fear card on this one so he can look tough in the run up to the general election And they believe Tony Blair is using the issue to suggest the Tories are soft on terrorism. Why on earth will the prime minister not simply take up the Tories' offer to extend the existing powers temporarily to allow proper parliamentary debate of the laws, he demanded. The prime minister claims this is the clearest indication that it is the Tories who are playing politics with the issue by attempting to score cheap political points in parliament. Is not the opposition against to the proposed laws "in principle", in which case delaying a decision for further debate would be pointless?
 
 What this is really about, believes Mr Blair, is the Tories spotting an opportunity to embarrass, maybe even defeat the government. And that is more important to them than national security. Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy avoided suggesting anyone was playing politics with the issue. He preferred to state that, as with other issues like ID cards, the government's immediate instinct was authoritarian.
 
 As is his habit nowadays, the prime minister was less rough with Mr Kennedy than he had been with Mr Howard - he prefers a more exasperated tone suggesting he believes the Lib Dems have, once again, just missed the point. Apart from all that, it was electioneering as usual. The very first question to the prime minister from Derby North's Bob Laxton asked him, in effect, if he would carry on the excellent policy of pouring more resources into schools. Later Birmingham's Sion Simon even went so far as to suggest the Tories were such a shower that we should have the general election now. The prime minister almost blushed. This was not the appropriate place to announce election day, he stammered. But can anyone be in any doubt that that announcement is just days away - an announcement coming in the week beginning 4 April for an election on 5 May is where the big money is in the Commons. And perhaps that simple fact alone means everyone is seen to be playing politics with just about everything at the moment.
llama3.2:1b: The Prime Minister's questions revealed a disagreement between Michael Howard and Tony Blair over the government's plans for anti-terror measures. The Tories believe the Prime Minister is "ramming" through Parliament without proper debate, while the opposition argues that delaying a decision would be pointless as it is in principle against their stance.
llama3.2:3b: Prime Minister Tony Blair claims opposition, led by Michael Howard and Charles Kennedy, is playing politics with security measures. Blair suggests they are using terrorism to score cheap points rather than focusing on national security. The Prime Minister argues this delay for further debate would be pointless as the opposition's stance is against the laws "in principle".
gemma2:2b: Michael Howard accuses Prime Minister Blair of using anti-terror measures as a political tool to gain advantage ahead of the general election. The Tories believe they are being unfairly painted as "soft" on terrorism, while the Prime Minister maintains that their opposition is merely against the proposed laws in principle and that delaying action would be pointless.  Charles Kennedy, leader of the Liberal Democrats, avoids taking sides on the accusation of political maneuvering but highlights the government's general tendency towards authoritarianism. The Prime Minister uses his usual electioneering tactics to deflect accusations from both Howard and Kennedy, even when directly challenged about an impending election announcement.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Here are the key ideas and details from the text:

1. Prime Minister Howard claims the Tories are "ramming" through Parliament's controversial anti-terror measures without proper debate.
2. They believe Tony Blair is using these issues as a way to suggest the Conservatives are soft on terrorism.
3. The prime minister claims this is the clearest indication that it is the Tories who are playing politics with the issue by attempting to score cheap political points in Parliament.
4. The opposition (Liberal Democrats) believes the government's reaction to these measures is an attempt to embarrass them.
5. Prime Minister Blair prefers a more exasperated tone and seems uncomfortable discussing the issues openly, as he avoided previous questions about the Tories' actions.
6. This information was intended for general election day in April 2017.
7. Prime Minister Howard almost blushed at the suggestion that his announcement is coming soon.
8. The issue of anti-terror measures has become a major election issue this year, as electioneering is becoming more prominent.

In summary, key ideas and details from the text are:

* Prime Minister Howard claims the Tories are "ramming" through Parliament's controversial anti-terror measures without proper debate.
* They believe Tony Blair is using these issues as an attempt to score cheap political points in Parliament.
* The opposition (Liberal Democrats) believes the government's reaction to these measures is an attempt to embarrass them.
* Prime Minister Blair prefers a more exasperated tone and seems uncomfortable discussing the issues openly, as he avoided previous questions about the Tories' actions.
* This information was intended for general election day in April 2017.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Prime Minister Tony Blair's opponents accuse him of playing political games over security legislation, suggesting it's a tactic for damaging his re-election bid rather than prioritizing national security. The prime minister claims Parliament should debate laws without delay, while Blair dismisses opposition as merely trying to embarrass or defeat the government. Questions about schools and elections further indicate electioneering tactics.
qwen2.5:3b: Prime Minister's Questions focused on the debate over controversial new anti-terror measures. Michael Howard claimed Prime Minister Tony Blair was rushing through the laws without proper parliamentary scrutiny, accusing Tories of using fear and political points. Liberal Democrat Charles Kennedy suggested neither party was playing politics but that their immediate instinct towards authoritarianism affected national security. The discussions highlighted the election season’s impact on policy debates.
opencoder:1.5b:
Prime Minister's Questions 

So, who, if anyone, is playing politics with the security of the nation? 

The prime minister has questioned and debated the issue of national security without proper reason. He claims that it is the Tories who are using this issue to suggest they are soft on terrorism, but the government insists that it is the prime minister who "ramming" through Parliament to enforce anti-terror measures. The prime minister, however, agrees that allowing proper parliamentary debate would be a more constructive approach. The Tories believe that a delay in a decision for further debate will not be pointless. 

The reality of this matter is that Mr Blair, the Prime Minister's opponent against various political and security issues, has consistently insisted on making a point of arguing over these matters with the Tories. And it is more important to them than national security - as such, he is seen to be playing politics with every aspect of life at the moment. He prefers an exasperated tone when others do suggest that Lib Dems may have missed the point.

tinyllama:1.1b: The passage mentions that primeminister Michael Howard's questions suggest the prime minister is using fear as a "ramming" factor on the controversial new anti-terror measures, without providing any specific details. The passage also highlights that opposition leader Charles Kennedy avoided suggesting anyone was playing politics with the issue and instead stated that as with ID cards, the government's immediate instinct was authoritarian. In conclusion, the passage suggests that Tony Blair is using the controversial new laws to score cheap political points in Parliament and could be seen by some as playing politics with national security.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The text provides a brief summary of the given passage, highlighting important aspects and insights while avoiding unnecessary elaboration and reasoning process. It conveys that the prime minister's (PM) questioning of security measures comes from an expectation of an election, with implications for national security.
phi:2.7b: The prime minister's questions are focused around allegations of political gamesmanship regarding national security measures, particularly in relation to a controversial anti-terror law. The opposition party accuses the government of using the issue as a platform for gaining political points and suggests they are taking more of an authoritarian stance than necessary. Meanwhile, the prime minister is accusing the opposition of being too concerned with scoring cheap political points rather than prioritizing national security concerns. Liberal Democrats' leader Charles Kennedy prefers to avoid suggesting anyone is playing politics and believes that the government's instinct in this situation is authoritarian. The question of whether or not to extend temporary powers for parliamentary debate on the law continues to be a source of contention between parties, with the opposition party opposing it outright. Meanwhile, the prime minister appears to be preoccupied with electioneering efforts as an early announcement of the election date approaches.
orca-mini:3b: The text discusses claims of political games being played with national security by the prime minister and opposition parties. The opposition parties believe the prime minister is trying to score cheap political points by rushing through new anti-terror measures without proper debate, while the prime minister believes the opposition is simply opposing the measures for their own political gain.
hermes3:3b:

Blair believes Tories try to embarrass govt more than ensuring safety, while Lib Dem leader Charles Kennedy misses point on authoritarian instincts.
Electioneering dominates questions, e.g. Bob Laxton asking about school resources; Sion Simon calling Tories "a shower" for an election now.

Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy avoids explicitly accusing anyone of playing politics but suggests that the government's immediate instinct is authoritarian. The prime minister deflects questions, reminding everyone that an election announcement is imminent.

Blair counters that the Tories are the ones playing politics, trying to embarrass the government rather than prioritizing national security. stablelm2:1.6b: Prime minister Michael Howard accuses Tony Blair and the prime minister of attempting to push through anti-terror measures without proper debate, while some believe they are using the issue for political gain before an election. The opposition argues that delaying a decision for further debate would be pointless, but Prime Minister Blair believes it's about the Tories trying to embarrass the government. Electioneering is prevalent, and it's suspected that announcements of elections are just days away.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
During Prime Minister's Questions, the opposition Conservative Party, led by Michael Howard, accused Prime Minister Tony Blair of rushing through controversial anti-terrorism measures without adequate parliamentary debate, suggesting it was an attempt to score political points ahead of the general election. The Conservatives proposed extending existing powers temporarily for further discussion, but the prime minister refused, claiming that delay would be futile since the opposition's stance is "in principle" against the laws.

In contrast, Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy maintained a more neutral view, stating the government's initial approach was authoritarian, much like their stance on ID cards. The prime minister spoke to Kennedy in a less confrontational manner, implying the Lib Dems were merely missing the mark.

The prime minister also faced questions about school funding from Derby North's Bob Laxton and Birmingham's Sion Simon, who suggested holding an early election (May 5) for additional resources. This hint at an upcoming poll underscored the pervasive political nature of the debate.

Key takeaway: All parties acknowledged the issue was about politics rather than national security, with each emphasizing their commitment to different policies and priorities ahead of the general election.
reference: The prime minister claims this is the clearest indication that it is the Tories who are playing politics with the issue by attempting to score cheap political points in parliament.He didn't say so, but the Tories believe the prime minister is playing the fear card on this one so he can look tough in the run up to the general election And they believe Tony Blair is using the issue to suggest the Tories are soft on terrorism.Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy avoided suggesting anyone was playing politics with the issue.So who, if anyone, is playing politics with the security of the nation?As is his habit nowadays, the prime minister was less rough with Mr Kennedy than he had been with Mr Howard - he prefers a more exasperated tone suggesting he believes the Lib Dems have, once again, just missed the point.The prime minister almost blushed.Why on earth will the prime minister not simply take up the Tories' offer to extend the existing powers temporarily to allow proper parliamentary debate of the laws, he demanded.Michael Howard has no doubt it is the prime minister who, he claims, is "ramming" through Parliament the controversial new anti-terror measures without proper debate.
